newsitem.title: FRANCE: Arthuis sees overshoot in privatisation receipts.
newsitem.headline: Arthuis sees overshoot in privatisation receipts.

text.p: French Finance Minister Jean Arthuis confirmed in an interview published on Tuesday that privatisation receipts this year would largely exceed the 27 billion francs forecast in the 1997 budget.
"This estimate will be significantly overtaken," he said in an interview with the afternoon daily Le Monde.
The government has already said it expects to raise around 30 to 50 billion francs through the sale of a minority stake in France Telecom in May.
Arthuis said other planned privatisations this year included defence electronics group Thomson-CSF, CIC, the banking arm of insurer Groupe GAN, Banque Hervet and Societe Marseillaise de Credit.
He repeated that the amount of the share capital to be sold in France Telecom, and the value of its shares, had yet to be decided, although the state would retain a stake of at least 51 percent.
"But I am very committed to the idea of this being a big move for popular shareholding, bringing together users of France Telecom and its workers," he said.
He also confirmed that the government was working on a reform of the French Treasury, which would create a special team to oversee state-owned companies.

French newspapers have said the government is considering bringing in people from the private sector to the Treasury to help run state companies, some of which have run up big losses in recent years and now require state bailouts.
All money raised from privatisations this year is expected to be used to fund capital injections into state companies.
